body:
Yeah this is one major concept which convinces me of the veracity of the bible, which is that it is the best explanation for all of what we otherwise have to find absurd explanations or theories to explain or make sense of the way things are.

In other words, setting faith aside, the bible can be, for the most part, independently verified as legitimate, to include by science.  Much of the secular science i pay attention to ends up re-enforcing my belief in God and the bible as a whole.

body:
They're both in denial about collectivism and individualism.

The communist thinks everyone is, or ought to be, in the same community regardless of their individual preferences (the great levelling), while the libertarian doesn't seem to acknowledge there being a community at all (total atomization and [Peterson stupidity](https://archive.vn/FUD3d/12ff11dbd81ecdd66928cff3f679ba860310af4a.jpg)). 

The proper position is to have a community of people that are either blood-related or friends, with a prioritization given to the more proximal than the more distal, and to not coerce people that don't want to associate with you. Ideally, we'd be able to have geographic, legal and other separation for this to be the most efficient.

body:
>In other words, setting faith aside, the bible can be, for the most part, independently verified as legitimate, to include by science. Much of the secular science i pay attention to endz up re-enforicng my belief in God and the bible as a whole.

Two ways of knowing are through reason and empirically. Ideally they should work hand-in-hand, and no one should IFLscience.

>Much of the secular science i pay attention to endz up re-enforicng my belief in God and the bible as a whole.

I've come to the conclusion that believing in God or the concept of God is better than the relativistic nonsense. It's too atomizing and results in a life with less meaning. Truth exists, therefore God exists (or the concept of God). I know this is a tautology but the world needs to have order and we see order everywhere. I think the benefits of believing in God. either as a figure or as a concept (truth, goodness, beauty, right, justice, etc.) far outweigh the negation and relativizing that we see today. It seems that God has been anthropomorphized, perverted/desecrated, made relativistic and has been dethroned/usurped/replaced (I know at that point it's no longer God by definition). 

Much like the French Revolution dethroning France, then Austria-Hungary, Germany, and Russia, the same devolution happened religiously with the spread of atheism and secularization. They've destroyed many [Chesterton Fences](https://fs.blog/2020/03/chestertons-fence/) on their march to egalitarianism.

>There exists in such a case a certain institution or law; let us say, for the sake of simplicity, a fence or gate erected across a road. The more modern type of reformer goes gaily up to it and says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the use of this; let us clear it away.‚Äù To which the more intelligent type of reformer will do well to answer: ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt see the use of it, I certainly won‚Äôt let you clear it away. Go away and think. Then, when you can come back and tell me that you do see the use of it, I may allow you to destroy it.‚Äù

Much of the secular science i pay attention to endz up re-enforicng my belief in God and the bible as a whole.

I've come to the conclusion that believing in God or the concept of God is better than the relativistic nonsense. It's too atomizing and results in a life with less meaning. Truth exists, therefore God exists (or the concept of God). I know this is a tautology but the world needs to have order and we see order everywhere. I think the benefits of believing in God. either as a figure or as a concept (truth, goodness, beauty, right, justice, etc.) far outweigh the negation and relativizing that we see today. It seems that God has been anthropomorphized, perverted/desecrated, made relativistic and has been dethroned/usurped/replaced (I know at that point it's no longer God by definition).

Much like the French Revolution dethroning France, then Austria-Hungary, Germany, and Russia, the same devolution happened religiously with the spread of atheism and secularization. They've destroyed many Chesterton Fences on their march to egalitarianism.

There exists in such a case a certain institution or law; let us say, for the sake of simplicity, a fence or gate erected across a road. The more modern type of reformer goes gaily up to it and says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the use of this; let us clear it away.‚Äù To which the more intelligent type of reformer will do well to answer: ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt see the use of it, I certainly won‚Äôt let you clear it away. Go away and think. Then, when you can come back and tell me that you do see the use of it, I may allow you to destroy it.‚Äù

parent.body:
They're both in denial about collectivism and individualism.

The communist thinks everyone is, or ought to be, in the same community regardless of their individual preferences (the great levelling), while the libertarian doesn't seem to acknowledge there being a community at all (total atomization and [Peterson stupidity](https://archive.vn/FUD3d/12ff11dbd81ecdd66928cff3f679ba860310af4a.jpg)). 

The proper position is to have a community of people that are either blood-related or friends, with a prioritization given to the more proximal than the more distal, and to not coerce people that don't want to associate with you. Ideally, we'd be able to have geographic, legal and other separation for this to be the most efficient.

body:
Removal or serious reduction in the state necessarily leads to greater roles for local communities, religious organizations, and especially families. Any nominal libertarian who thinks atomization is compatible with a drastic rollback in the state is incoherent and likely just latching on thoughtlessly to surface-level ideas. 

Hoppe has been pointed out, but it's not just him; the Mises Institute crowd and associates are overwhelmingly concerned with more natural communities and localism. The Libertarian Party and the mainstream cretins at Cato are essentially spineless panderers desperately trying to get leftists on board, in the process cripplingly compromising their own nominal principles.

body:
I dont have anything in particular; i don't go too deep into it, just watch stuff on youtube are skim through books here and there, but the basic premise suggests that particles behave differently when they are observed than when they aren't.  This ties in to the schrodinger's box paradox, wherein until the cat is observed, it is both alive and dead. The semantics of such a claim can be funky, but it leads a person like me to believe that the determining factor is something aside from the particles themselves. 

Another presenter i watched in a youtube video explained it thus: that a ball thrown over a wall, except it be thrown *above* the wall, will not go past the wall, and yet the probabilistic determination (i probably didn't word that right) allows for the ball to sometimes pass through the wall.

Also the notion that atoms, and thus we, and everything we see, is 99%+ empty space, which would mean in theory that two people could occupy the same physical space were one or both able to circumvent the electromagnetic forces.


Also, that if a person had complete control over said electrons, they could cause them to rotate with such timing that light would pass through them instead of being reflected to an observer, thus things, or people, could exist right in front of our face, and we could not see them.
body_html:
I dont have anything in particular; i don't go too deep into it, just watch stuff on youtube are skim through books here and there, but the basic premise suggests that particles behave differently when they are observed than when they aren't. This ties in to the schrodinger's box paradox, wherein until the cat is observed, it is both alive and dead. The semantics of such a claim can be funky, but it leads a person like me to believe that the determining factor is something aside from the particles themselves.

Another presenter i watched in a youtube video explained it thus: that a ball thrown over a wall, except it be thrown above the wall, will not go past the wall, and yet the probabilistic determination (i probably didn't word that right) allows for the ball to sometimes pass through the wall.

Also the notion that atoms, and thus we, and everything we see, is 99%+ empty space, which would mean in theory that two people could occupy the same physical space were one or both able to circumvent the electromagnetic forces.

Also, that if a person had complete control over said electrons, they could cause them to rotate with such timing that light would pass through them instead of being reflected to an observer, thus things, or people, could exist right in front of our face, and we could not see them.

body:
Okay. Sounds complex. I've heard of the observing a thing changes a thing before.

>Also the notion that atoms, and thus we, and everything we see, is 99%+ empty space, which would mean in theory that two people could occupy the same physical space were one or both able to circumvent the electromagnetic forces.

I see what you're getting at but not really. Even though the thing about atoms and the space between them is correct, there are interactions, bonds, forces, etc., that are occurring between those particles, despite the magnitude of the gaps between them. So while all the particles that make up two people could fit into the space that a single body occupies, they would not really be in the same spot, and they would not maintain their unique structures.

body:
>If he postulates a ton of parallel universes, and people respect such theory, why then is it hard to imagine one extra parallel universe wherein angels operate and influence this reality?

Probably because it would be hard to verify.

Think of all the claims of astronomers that have said they discovered a new planet, it might be habitable, etc. That's fine and all but we haven't actually ever verified that what they are measuring is actually what is. It's just math and equations. So they haven't even empirically discovered it yet, they've just done things on paper/computers.

With respect to the multiverse hypothesis, and let me flip it on it's head for you. You're suggesting there could be some all powerful entity that can influence across this multiverse. It's implied that there is essentially an infinite number of universes then, so that would mean that there would also exist an all powerful entity that could destroy a universe across the multiverse as well. It would be malicious and capable. We still exist so maybe it hasn't gotten to us yet, but this would also suggest that there actually isn't a multiverse.

It's all science fiction and speculation though.

parent.body:
I consider anyone that places priority on human ideologies, (even anti-human ideologies,) "humanist" because they think that these human generated opions or feelings somehow accurately define the universe rather than being subjective mental contortioning.

They "have faith" in their twisted version of morality, and imagine that it is a kind of immutable truth rather than just a machine for displacing blame.

post.body:
Original sin has been replaced by inhereted white guilt/patriarchal dominion. Original sin is a superior premise as it applies to everyone instead of picking and choosing demographics. Identity politics is inherently racist.

Traditional family values and marriage creates more productive and psychologically stable individuals, whether or not they actually subscribe to any of the associated religious traditions.
